00:15:32.140 | then I get 1% of the loan back as a fee.
00:15:35.900 | So if I charge them 8 1/2%, I get two points back.
00:15:40.900 | So if it's $100,000 piece of property
00:15:44.180 | and the bank says your interest rate is gonna be 8%
00:15:48.540 | and I tell you 8.5 and I'm charging you a $3,500 broker fee,
00:15:53.540 | now I'm making $5,500.

00:16:51.060 | meaning creating fake identities.
00:16:54.220 | What does it take to do that, to do that well?
00:16:57.220 | - So, your credit profile is made up of your,
00:17:02.540 | your name, date of birth, your address,

00:17:09.660 | and then there's other things, where you work,
00:17:12.580 | that sort of thing.
00:17:13.540 | But what people don't realize is
00:17:18.180 | there's so many people out there that think
00:17:20.980 | that the credit bureaus already know who you are, right?
00:17:24.820 | But the truth is, the first time the credit bureau
00:17:26.620 | has ever heard about you was when you told them.
00:17:29.460 | The first time you applied for a credit card,
00:17:31.580 | you, they created a credit profile at that moment.
00:17:34.700 | Prior to that, they had no idea.
00:17:36.180 | So the first time you apply, you give them your full name,
00:17:41.100 | date of birth, social security number, and your address.
00:17:44.780 | And they create a credit profile,
00:17:47.300 | and they say, hey, no record found of this person.
00:17:50.380 | He has no credit, nothing, probably got denied.
00:17:53.300 | Well, what I realized through the course of,
00:17:57.300 | 'cause eventually I end up leaving that one company,
00:18:00.540 | and I open my own mortgage company.

00:18:05.620 | I was on the inside.

00:33:13.300 | - So, what do you do with a phantom borrower?

00:33:17.640 | - So, I think most people,

00:33:52.400 | - So, you can go through this whole process

00:33:55.720 | paying it off, building up credit,
00:33:57.160 | and then you get $15,000 at the end, or so.
00:33:59.320 | - Right, you get 15, maybe,
00:34:00.920 | if you wanna keep making the payments,

00:34:03.360 | you could probably get 15,000, maybe.
00:34:06.720 | You could maybe get 20, 30,000,
00:34:08.560 | and a bunch of little smaller ones.
00:34:10.080 | You get 7,500, 'cause I did,

00:51:48.400 | Like, they don't know.

00:52:21.020 | and we got a 1-800 number you could call,

00:52:31.480 | which, by this point,

00:52:38.020 | 'Cause a lot of times, people,
00:52:39.340 | they have good enough credit to borrow 95% or 90%,

00:55:36.340 | So it's a real person that's buying the house.
00:55:38.300 | He's got perfect credit.

00:55:42.560 | to get a couple hundred thousand in his pocket.

01:07:58.720 | And I think that if you're committing crime,

01:08:06.680 | I did a bunch of scumbag things.

01:08:16.660 | You boil down to it, that's what I am.

01:08:24.560 | and then expect those same scumbags
01:08:26.600 | to suddenly abide by some kind of a street code
01:08:31.560 | and not roll over on you.

03:04:50.100 | So let's say you buy a house for $250,000

04:21:12.900 | I don't know.
04:21:13.740 | He was just ineffective, incompetent.

04:21:20.420 | - Oh, you met her eventually.
04:21:21.380 | - Of course I did, of course.
04:21:23.500 | She's 5'11", wearing three-inch heels.

04:21:32.940 | one of the angriest human beings I've ever met.
04:21:36.460 | And every FBI agent that I've met since then

04:21:53.120 | - Secret Service is a little bit more professional.
04:21:56.700 | - Very personal, very, it's their job.
04:21:58.340 | It's like, hey, this is just my job.
04:21:59.860 | They're polite, professional, that's it.
04:22:02.700 | So it's just, this is just, this is my nine to five.

04:36:01.880 | you know, that I was stoic, and I stood there,
04:36:04.960 | and I took it in.

04:36:15.240 | I was just, how did I get 26?

04:36:24.000 | I've met guys that kidnapped guys that got 15.
04:36:27.620 | - 26.
04:36:31.360 | - So yeah, I--
04:36:33.520 | - Were you scared?
04:36:35.860 | - I mean, you know, does the Pope wear a funny hat?
04:36:38.540 | Like, of course I was scared, I was terrified.
04:36:41.040 | I mean, you know, but I kept telling myself,
04:36:44.100 | ah, they're gonna reduce the sentence,
04:36:45.780 | they'll reduce it, they'll reduce it, they'll reduce it.
04:36:47.540 | Like, okay, okay, okay, it's gonna be okay,
04:36:49.460 | it's gonna be okay.
04:36:50.420 | You know, but it wasn't okay.
04:36:52.660 | I got moved to Coleman, the Coleman Complex
04:36:57.660 | in Coleman, Florida, the Federal Correctional
04:37:02.100 | Coleman Complex in Coleman, Florida,
04:37:04.580 | which is the largest complex in the nation,
04:37:07.420 | federal complex in the nation.
04:37:08.900 | At that time, there was a camp, which was a female camp.
04:37:13.900 | There was a low-security prison for men,
04:37:19.460 | a medium-security prison, and two penitentiaries.
04:37:22.280 | And so I get moved to the medium.
04:37:26.460 | Now, I'm moved to the medium not because,
04:37:28.260 | like, that's where, like, real criminals go, right?
04:37:30.180 | Like, I'm a soft white boy.
04:37:33.580 | Like, I'm no danger to anybody.
04:37:34.900 | Like, I hurt someone's feelings once.
04:37:37.140 | But other than that, I'm not gonna be a problem.
04:37:40.980 | But if you have more than 20 years to serve,
04:37:45.440 | you have to go to a medium.
04:37:46.940 | So even though my security level said
04:37:48.700 | this guy should be in a camp, I had 20 years.
04:37:53.560 | So if you have, you can't go to a camp
04:37:55.460 | till you have less than 10.
04:37:57.020 | So as soon as I am given 26 years,
04:38:00.420 | they knock off three, but you still have three years
04:38:02.460 | to get below 20, so they go to the medium.
04:38:04.100 | So I go to the medium, and there are guys getting stabbed.
04:38:06.780 | The very first day, people are being stabbed.
04:38:08.940 | I get locked into, go to my cell, meet my cellie.
04:38:13.140 | They scream lockdown.
04:38:15.060 | Somebody got stabbed in the rec yard.
04:38:17.260 | I remember I asked my cellie,
04:38:18.580 | which I met 20 minutes earlier, I was like,
04:38:20.620 | what's, you know, he's like,
04:38:21.460 | "Hey, we gotta get in the cell."
04:38:22.580 | I was like, "What's going on?"
04:38:23.580 | He goes, "Somebody got stabbed in the yard."
04:38:24.780 | I go, "Somebody just got killed?"
04:38:26.540 | And he goes, "Nah, they just stabbed him up a little bit."
04:38:29.060 | And I thought, you're in a place
04:38:31.860 | where they stabbed him up a little bit.

04:38:35.900 | You gotta get out of here.
04:38:37.820 | So anyway, I go to the medium, I'm there.

04:38:44.180 | in the county, and they're county jails,

04:52:47.960 | - Whatever you want to say about Bubba,
04:52:49.760 | he was a respectful man.

04:52:54.280 | So that went on, but I mean, when I say that went on,
04:52:56.780 | I mean, like literally like that's a couple of times.
04:52:59.260 | He said the same thing to a guy in line one time.
04:53:02.220 | Guy came up to me later and said, look, man,
04:53:03.700 | but I'm sorry, Matt, he was standing next to me in line.
04:53:05.580 | Bubba said something to him.
04:53:06.580 | He went like 10 or 15 people back and stood in line.
04:53:09.620 | Later on, he came up to me, Matt, I'm sorry, bro,
04:53:12.640 | but you know, I said, bro, I said, look, I get it.
04:53:17.160 | We're not friends.
04:53:18.000 | Don't worry about it.
04:53:18.820 | And here's the thing.
04:53:19.980 | At some point there, I got, I ended up getting,
04:53:24.120 | well, the FBI started showing up there at the prison,
04:53:27.960 | questioning me about my files in Tampa,
04:53:32.280 | the room of the 12 guys that were indicted.
04:53:34.840 | They show up and they start asking me about it.

05:25:19.340 | And they go and they raid Jimmy and he gets arrested.
05:25:22.300 | You're gonna get something off of that.
05:25:23.740 | Not a lot, but you're gonna get something.
05:25:25.840 | And they could just say, "We were gonna bust him anyway.
05:25:31.160 | "We were already onto him."
05:25:33.220 | Now the next level would be you wear a wire.
05:25:36.380 | So I wore a wire and I was in danger.
05:25:41.220 | Now keep in mind, I'm asking this guy questions
05:25:43.100 | inside federal prison.
05:25:44.520 | I'm in danger.
05:25:46.020 | So whatever, that's like the next level.
05:25:48.820 | You're taking an active participation in the investigation.
05:25:53.820 | And the third level would be you actually get on the stand
05:25:58.840 | and you cooperate and you testify.
05:26:02.820 | Now there's no better cooperation than that.
05:26:05.020 | So when Wilson says to me,
05:26:09.660 | "They're gonna move me back to South Carolina.
05:26:13.600 | "They've indicted me.
05:26:15.060 | "They've charged me.

05:26:31.660 | "Hey, there's some good to this guy."

05:26:49.780 | - It does, but it also increases my ability
05:26:52.940 | to get more off my sentence.

05:26:58.180 | he's on what's called the packout, right?

05:41:57.940 | I had guys in prison cutting me checks
05:42:03.460 | so that I could build a website

05:42:12.860 | slowly, it takes forever, putting pictures up,
05:42:16.980 | I'm trying to figure out how Photoshop works,
05:42:21.540 | how all this stuff.
05:42:23.080 | The whole time I wanted to start,
05:42:26.220 | 'cause the last one, I was just getting out of prison,
05:42:28.060 | everybody kept telling me like,
05:42:29.020 | bro, you gotta start a podcast,
05:42:30.220 | you gotta start a true crime podcast.
05:42:32.460 | And I don't know what a podcast is.
05:42:34.300 | The term podcast came into existence in 2009
05:42:37.540 | when I'd been locked up three years.
05:42:39.620 | I'd never been on YouTube.
05:42:41.620 | So by the time I get out, the last year or two,
05:42:46.060 | guys are coming up to me, giving me magazines,
05:42:47.900 | like this is what a pod, you need to read.
05:42:49.740 | Look, true crime's huge.
05:42:51.780 | And you have to think,
05:42:52.620 | guys are asking me every couple of days,
